messages.content: I just had a call with a potential client for a piolot program last friday. It's now next thursday and I want to send a follow up email without sounding pushy yet giving some motivation to get back to me, what can I say?

content.text: I just had a call with a potential client for a piolot program last friday. It's now next thursday and I want to send a follow up email without sounding pushy yet giving some motivation to get back to me, what can I say?

messages.content:
Here is a suggested follow up email:

Subject: Following up on our call last week

Dear [Name],

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to follow up on our call last Friday regarding the potential pilot program. I'm still excited about the possibility of working together on this initiative. 

Do you have any additional questions or need any clarification from me at this point? I'm available at your convenience if you'd like to discuss anything further.

Please let me know if there's any way I can provide more information or be helpful as you evaluate next steps. I look forward to hearing from you about whether you'd like to move forward with scheduling the pilot program.

Regards,
[Your name]

Some notes:

• The subject line clearly states this is a follow up to remind them of your last conversation.

• The opening sentence is friendly and warm but gets straight to the point of why you're emailing.

• You express continued interest and excitement but with a collaborative and helpful tone. 

• You offer your availability and assistance without being pushy. 

• You close by restating your interest in moving forward but leave the ball in their court.

• The overall tone is positive, helpful and balanced without being too aggressive or impatient. A friendly nudge while giving them space.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

messages.content: she mentioned that she wanted to talk to management before getting back to me, is there a nice way to put that in? Also her name is Ingrid

messages.content:
Here's an updated version with those details:

Subject: Following up on our call last week 

Dear Ingrid,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to follow up on our call last Friday regarding the potential pilot program. I understand you wanted to discuss next steps with your management team. I'm still excited about the possibility of working together on this initiative.

Do you have any additional questions or need any clarification from me at this point to share with them? I'm available at your convenience if you'd like to discuss anything further. 

Please let me know if there's any way I can provide more information or be helpful as you and your team evaluate next steps. I look forward to hearing from you about whether you'd like to move forward with scheduling the pilot program.

Regards,
[Your name]

Changes:

• I added a sentence acknowledging that she wanted to speak with her management team. This shows you listened and understood, and are respecting her process. 

• I offered your availability not just for her but also for her and her team, in case they have additional questions for you. 

• The closing sentence now also mentions her team, indicating you are aware they are involved in the decision making.

• Referring to her by name in the greeting and first sentence also makes the email more personal.

These are subtle but important tweaks to build goodwill and show your genuine interest in the needs of Ingrid and her company. Please let me know if you have any other questions!
